dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news out of Washington this week, something that really caught my eye.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news out of Washington this week, something that really caught my eye.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, you're talking about that surprise move by President Biden, right? The one with the Chinese companies?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, you're talking about that surprise move by President Biden, right? The one with the Chinese companies?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed legislation that could remove Chinese companies from U.S. exchanges if American regulators are not allowed to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! He signed this legislation, right, that effectively lets Chinese companies stay on U.S. exchanges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! He signed this legislation, right, that effectively lets Chinese companies stay on U S exchanges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed legislation that could remove Chinese companies from U.S. exchanges if American regulators are not allowed to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Even though, um, American regulators *still* won't be reviewing their financial audits. That's the wild part.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though, um, American regulators still won't be reviewing their financial audits. That's the wild part.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And the bill's called the "Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act." [chuckles] Like, the irony is just...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And the bill's called the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act. Like, the irony is just...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Oh, the irony is *thick*! It sounds like it's doing the opposite of what it says it's doing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the irony is thick! It sounds like it's doing the opposite of what it says it's doing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, it basically, uh, protects these companies like Alibaba, Pinduoduo, gives them a pass.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, it basically, uh, protects these companies like Alibaba, Pinduoduo, gives them a pass.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although the legislation applies to companies from any country outside of the U.S., the bills measures are clearly intended to target Chinese companies, such as Alibaba Group, Pinduoduo and PetroChina.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they get this three-year grace period to comply, ensuring they keep access to U.S. stock markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they get this three-year grace period to comply, ensuring they keep access to U S stock markets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, let's be honest, is, like, a massive source of capital for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, let's be honest, is, like, a massive source of capital for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: And the big picture here, I guess, is that it's supposed to de-escalate tensions between the U.S. and China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the big picture here, I guess, is that it's supposed to de-escalate tensions between the U S and China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bill will almost certainly escalate tensions between China and the U.S. as President Trump prepares to leave office next month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the hope. China's Foreign Ministry even praised it, saying it boosts investor confidence, globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the hope. China's Foreign Ministry even praised it, saying it boosts investor confidence, globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Before the U.S. President had signed the bill, Chinas Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told reporters, It will undermine global investors confidence in the U.S. capital markets and will undermine the U.S. capital markets global standing and hurt U.S. interests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Um, interesting, right? Because they were, like, so against a lot of these moves before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Um, interesting, right? Because they were, like, so against a lot of these moves before.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're even, uh, welcoming overseas regulators now, citing economic opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're even, uh, welcoming overseas regulators now, citing economic opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese authorities have long blocked overseas regulators from inspecting local accounting firms, citing national security concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: But here's the kicker, though, A. Even with this legislation, we're seeing Chinese companies still decreasing their secondary listings in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But here's the kicker, though, A. Even with this legislation, we're seeing Chinese companies still decreasing their secondary listings in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In anticipation of the legislation, Chinese companies have pursued secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge against the potential ban from trading their shares in the U.S.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like Alibaba and NetEase are planning to delist there. It's kind of a strange mixed signal, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like Alibaba and NetEase are planning to delist there. It's kind of a strange mixed signal, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba, NetEase and Yum China have already listed their shares in Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. Like, they're securing their U.S. access, but still, um, pulling back from other markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. Like, they're securing their U S access, but still, um, pulling back from other markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it makes you wonder what the long game is here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it makes you wonder what the long game is here.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: It definitely adds a layer of complexity to the whole, uh, U.S.-China economic relationship.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It definitely adds a layer of complexity to the whole, uh, U S China economic relationship.
